headline: Christine Blasey Ford faces her own allegations
subHeadline: The ex-boyfriend of Kavanaugh accuser Christine Blasey Ford claims he saw Ford helping a woman prepare for a potential polygraph test -- a claim that contradicts Ford's sworn testimony; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

The FBI probe into Brett Kavanaugh could be finished in a matter of hours. The bureau expected to wrap things up as early as today. Sources telling Fox News a single copy of the report will be sent to Capitol Hill and the White House to read and then it's going to be kept in a safe in the senate judiciary committee. This all comes as Senator Chuck Grassley is demanding answers to stunning new allegations that contradict Christine Blasey Ford's testimony. This is not a trial. But ultimately, have enough questions been raised that we should not move on to another candidate?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In addition, former Secretary of State John Kerry, he's busy defending the late Ted Kennedy, the former senator scandals have been brought up, of course, during the Kavanaugh nomination.

utterances.speaker: FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE JOHN KERRY
utterances.sentences: People have been critical through the years with -- and he was critical of himself. He stood up and owned moments where he knew he'd stepped over the line. So, I think that - - and he wasn't about to be nominated to a lifetime position. In fact, he said to the people of Massachusetts, if you think I shouldn't stay here, then, you know, and he took those returns and then he was elected another six times. That's a very different thing from a lifetime confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, judge, let's take the conversation to Cory Booker. I'm sure my colleagues here want me to call him Spartacus. But let's take the conversation there because what he's saying is he's not even arguing that the FBI probe is being sort of bull rush and limited by the White House. He's saying that this is not a criminal trial. This is about Kavanaugh's credibility, his character, judicial temperament of a man who would sit on the Supreme Court for decades to come. What do you think? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't agree with him. I think that will be a surprise to all of you. Look, here's the bottom line, the man was accused of being a sexual predator, of being a gang rapist, and, you know, causing women to get drunk, and he's not supposed to lose his cool for even a little bit. The truth is he's been on the circuit court for 12 years. He's got the temperament. And I don't know how many people out there been in courtrooms, but I've spent 30 years in them. Judges flip out all the time, and that is not what I consider flipping out, what Kavanaugh did. But I think the saddest part of all this is that they're standing up and saying it doesn't matter what the truth is. There's enough smell here. Let's get rid of him. But what is this smell? The only smell I get here is about someone who doesn't know the fundamentals about an issue that she kept quiet about. It's about a guy who was accused by three women, and how this guy found three women who would wait 35 years to admit that they were sexually assaulted by him blows my mind. He must be a genius because all of these women now have suffered from repressed memory. And in the end, they're now coming out to attack him. It's all politics, period. End of the story.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What do you think, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I agree with Booker. It's not a trial. It's a show trial, Juan. Think about it. There's no crime scene. There's no physical evidence. There's no corroborating witnesses. There's nothing. There's absolutely nothing. So with that, what you have is people raising questions. Anybody can raise questions, Juan. You can raise questions about everything. But you know what? When you raise questions, you have to find answers. How do you find answers? You get the facts. Senate investigators are looking for the facts. Unfortunately, for Democrats, they don't have any facts. There are no facts on their side right now. And if you look at the context of -- let's just say, the rolling stone rape hoax, how in the context of that can any Democrat say I have absolutely no doubt about what happened with judge Kavanaugh. These things happen all the time. There has to be some doubt there. Look at the Russian collusion situation. What happens if Mueller comes back and says we didn't find any evidence of collusion. What are the Democrats going to do then, Juan? They've convinced themselves for a year and a half there's collusion. And then when there's a fact-finding mission and they have no evidence, what will the Democrats going to do then? And just another side point, Justice Breyer was popped, arrested when he was at Stanford for underage drinking. No one made any stink about that at all. Total double standard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I see. And he denied it and said he was a choir boy and a virgin?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nope. He was popped for underage drinking and no one called him a raging alcoholic. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I get it. So the temperament question, Dana, is large for the Democrats. They say, you know, Thursday when Kavanaugh was testifying, he's talking about Clinton conspiracy theories like he's a right-wing radio talk show host, not a Supreme Court nominee.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Conservative start in a hole when they have these conversations because they usually based things on logic and fact and not emotion. And if you show emotion, then you're either hysterical or crazy or angry or mad. I actually think if you want to talk about temperament, he testified for 31 hours that week in front -- several days in front of the committee. Remember all the protesters screaming in the background? All the different -- he never once -- the only time that he decided he had to show what he really felt -- he had to lay it all out on the line, that's not about judicial temperament. That was about his reputation.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: And everyone said to him if you respond the way you did with Martha MacCallum, our Martha MacCallum, was a great interview, you were too laid- back. I mean, he was basically told this is your moments. You better get out there and show some emotion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, you're a man of great restraint.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you oftentimes play for me that very much a judicial.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to show you. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . temperament.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to show you how restrained I am. Ted Kennedy let a woman die. Bill Clinton has been accused of rape and assault by a number of women. So the Democratic Party should be renamed to Bill and Ted not so excellent adventure. They've treated women like spoils for the powerful, teachers, waitresses, campaign interns were all obliged to kiss the ring, that's to John Kerry. As for Booker, I commend him for his honesty. He has -- basically said that we will ruin a man and accept the collateral damage of his family, his family's torture because the cause is bigger than any individual. And the cause, the left-wing cause is bigger than the actual system itself. We can subvert a system. He would be a great -- Cory would be a great fascist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You think he's talking about the man's credibility given there's so many inconsistency.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's destroyed it. He could be a great -- he would have been great in East Germany. Booker, he missed his boat.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: But you know what? I think the most -- the greatest hypocrisy is when they say, Kerry says, that they stood up and owned their moments. They only stood up and owned their moments after the statute of limitations.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, they stood up with their pants down. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Didn't he wear like a fake neck brace, too, because he was the vet. Remember, he played the victim.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I see. So this woman standing out there, putting her name and her face in public, and all the.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, we hate her, Juan. We think she's evil. We think she's evil.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Go tribalism. Greg's monologue, yeah, and it's a good one on how a mob mentality has taken over college campuses, that's next. Have some fun. Watch The Five.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So clapping has been banned at Britain's University of Manchester student union. Clapping because it triggers anxiety and discourages people from attending events, and it will be replaced with a silent version of jazz hands which is said to encourage an environment of respect. Meanwhile, totally different story, a Massachusetts professor said that the label "veteran" should be expanded to include peace activists. I say the label "professor" should be expanded to include messy droolers. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } The one thing these things have in common besides lunacy is that they've both broken out of the asylum gates of a local university. The seed pods from the garden of stupid are now blooming in the real world. Why is that? Because no one wants to say: Man, that's really dumb. We're all bullied to silence now by the tyranny of grievance. Nobody wants to share the risk in calling out absurdity because that makes you a big meanie. Example: You're on a subway and a maniac gets on board, he's a babbling idiot, so everyone, what do they do? They look down at their phones. Why? Because no one wants to assume a piece of the risk, so they hide from the maniac. Then you realized the maniac is Bill de Blasio. Again, he's screaming inanities. Your head aches, he won't shut up. So now the joke's on you: You should have complained the moment de Blasio got on. You should have said shut up and get out of here, you're too loud and stupid for mass transit. Ideological excess spread when everyone looks the other way, whether it's on campus, in Congress, in media. But maybe for once, it's time, let's share the risk. It might be the only defense we have left. So, Jesse, they also said that clapping makes people with autism nervous, and I think that was a strategy to use a real issue to camouflage a silly idea because if clapping makes autistic or any anxious people nervous, it would be harmful to keep them from becoming accustomed to it. Like, what if they want to go to a soccer game, or what if they want to go to a rock concert. They can't because they wouldn't be used to clapping. This is absurd.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Are you sure this isn't an onion article? Do you double check?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I double checked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think we're getting spook here. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I better check with the producers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, we'll check after. Here's what I think, clapping isn't really for the people that are clapping. It's for the person that's performing, for instance, myself. Like, when I'm on stage, right, I need the clapping to know if my jokes are landing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: . to know if I have the audience on my side or not. I need that affirmation. They're missing that point. Also.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's all about Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The British are also overlooking something else, home team advantage. When you have a really loud crowd that forces the opposing team into taking timeouts, and they miscommunicate, and they're also missing that. Also, to your point about autism, this discriminates against blind people. Blind people can't see jazz hands, OK? Very discriminatory. And getting to the auditory situation, there were some loud noises around World War II when the Germans were dropping really loud bombs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: . on the British, and I think the British generation -- I think they survived. The anxiety there, that's real anxiety and they made it out OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Juan, what do you make of the idea of peace activists being called veterans?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think that's a great idea because I think diplomats -- they're really talking about -- I mean, you saw a peace activists like some kid marching in protest. They're not -- they're talking about people who have been diplomats, negotiators, people who made an effort, even people who've gone overseas like with the peace corps, the Mormons.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's not a military veteran.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I didn't say -- you've said military. They didn't say military, they said veterans. These are people who have given up themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So I'm a TV veteran.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I mean, when you think about it, they gave it themselves. They did a job, they've got paid for it. When you put your life on the line, you carry a weapon, that's a veteran. That's someone --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Our soldiers get paid for it.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes, they get paid for it, but you know what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not enough.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: The risk to them, if you do the classic risk-reward. This isn't a good idea to be in this line of work. The chances are someone is out there looking to kill you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think -- I don't think it's a great risk to go and put yourself on the line in the Peace Corps, let me tell you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But Juan, when you put a bullet in bin Laden's head, you're a peace activist, because now bin Laden can't make war.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go! There you go --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what, Jesse? You're a veteran.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, Dana, I do feel that the big problem these days is that nobody wants to share the risk. When there's -- when, like, there's a really dumb idea, there's a minority of activists that are so loud that they'll boycott you. They'll come after you. They'll hound you. So people just go, that's a good idea. Nobody wants to share the risk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Or -- well, as you were saying that, it does -- all of us for so long, when we hear these kinds of things, like, "Oh, that's stupid."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: "That's ridiculous." And then -- but you know, all of a sudden, now there's an entire generation of people --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- who think that you can't function in the real world without all of this mollycoddling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Mollycoddling?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I love that word.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a British word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like, you know, the speech codes on campus is a lousy idea. But academia, they -- they didn't want to share the risk. They didn't want people banging on their doors.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Remember the president of the -- of that university in Oklahoma --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- who stood up and he said, like, "We are not your babysitters. We're not your parents. We're here to challenge your thinking." And remember, he got all that attention but a lot of -- more people should be like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: More people should be willing to take a risk. You know, Manchester United, by the way, has the loudest soccer fans. I don't know if --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're not doing jazz hands.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're not doing jazz hands.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? Have you ever been to Gallaudet?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I tell you what: They do lots of things. By the way, they are very aggressive players, because they don't hear the whistles. So they keep going. But I will say this: jazz hands work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan is pro-jazz hands.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't have any problem with it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Hollywood liberals heading to Washington in an attempt to take down Kavanaugh. Will this just rally the Republican base even more? That's next.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Some Hollywood liberals recently teamed up with progressive group MoveOn.org to make a video attacking Brett Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Dear Professor Ford --

utterances.speaker: JULIANNE MOORE, ACTRESS
utterances.sentences: -- we know how difficult it is to stand up to powerful people.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We want to thank you for publicly sharing your story of sexual violence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The behavior you described was wrong.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Wrong.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE

utterances.sentences: -- and promoting justice.

utterances.sentences: He should not be confirmed.

utterances.speaker: AMERICA FERRERA, ACTRESS
utterances.sentences: He should not be confirmed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He should not be confirmed.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: And they're not stopping there. Tomorrow in Washington, anti-Trump celebrities, including John Legend, Lena Dunham, Alicia Keys, and Whoopi Goldberg, are set to protest against the president's Supreme Court nominee. OK, first of all --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait, why do we now break with tradition?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I want to start with you first.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: All right. Did any of these celebrities work for Hillary Clinton?

utterances.sentences: I guess like -- I think most of them supported Hillary.

utterances.sentences: Yes, but it didn't work for Hillary, did it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, it didn't work? They would come out. No, in fact --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: So is it going to work for Kavanaugh?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We're brilliant.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: You are brilliant. And that's why I'll go to next, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, thanks.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Who do you think is going to be more charged up? Where is the voter enthusiasm?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: If Hollywood -- Hollywood thinks they're going to help, they better hurry. Because just today there was a new poll that came out this afternoon that said that the Democratic -- the Democrats' edge in the generic ballot has evaporated in the last two weeks. So that should tell them something that they should be aware of. Because do you want to increase the possible political fortunes of a Cory Booker and a Kamala Harris at the expense of the Senate seats that you are actually running for in 2018? The other thing is, I do think that Hollywood can help in one way for the Democrats. And Republicans should be really aware of this. This is my issue. It is the registering of new voters. The numbers are astounding. I'll give you two examples. In Virginia this year, 135,000 new voters. New voters are usually the ones that vote -- they'll vote 99 percent of the time that first time, and they're probably Democrats. In Texas, this number just in: 400,000 new voters since March. And that's why these numbers are hard. Like, you see the polling about Beto O'Rourke and Ted Cruz. That's one of the reasons that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Can I interject there and say that the numbers also show that, given the Kavanaugh hearings and the controversy, 61 percent of Democrats say they're more likely to vote versus 52 percent of Republicans. And guess what? Forty-six, almost half of the people, say it has no impact.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: All right, Greg. Let me ask you this. Let's assume that Kavanaugh is confirmed. Does that mean that the Republican enthusiasm is lessened and that the Democrats are coming out at full charge? Or is it the opposite?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure. Normally, I would say that if Kavanaugh got in, you would see a blue wave; and if Kavanaugh didn't get in, you would have a huge red wave and then get an even more conservative judge. But I think people are so angry at what they've been seeing with Kavanaugh and now he's been mistreated, and how the media has been complicit in this, that you might get Kavanaugh and you might even get a mild red wave.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Red wave.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The one thing about Hollywood that is disturbing is that they were silent for decades over Harvey Weinstein. And they didn't come out until it was safe and easy for them. Because what it comes off as, it comes off as the cool kids exacting peer pressure on everybody else. They're at their cafeteria table saying if you don't agree with me, you're not cool. It doesn't work with Americans, women. We just look at you and we go, "Please." We don't take you seriously.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, not only did they, you know, not say anything about Harvey Weinstein. They didn't say anything about Roman Polanski. They loved up on Bill Clinton. So it's a little bit hypocritical for them. And these celebrities that are coming in and kind of bum-rushing the Capitol, this are not what you do when you want to send in someone to a swing vote or a swing district. This is Whoopi Goldberg. This is Lena Dunham. These people are really despised by half of the country. And then the independents, they're not really going to move the needle. This is not like the Million Man March. This is not like the Women's March. This isn't like the Tea Party. These are highly-trained Democratic activists that are taking off work, if they have a job, and they're going to harass public officials. And the only reason we're paying more attention to them is because they're nastier now. The other day someone went into an office of a congressman and assaulted them. And that's barely been reported. That's why it's gotten out of control.

utterances.sentences: How do you think it sells when Whoopi Goldberg says, "Donald Trump is not my president, and he take a huge dump on the country"? utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, we had discussions here at this table, Judge, about how Donald Trump talks, and how abusive his language can be to people. So she -- now that she does it, you want to condemn her.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: No, no, I've got my own issues. I was on "The View" when my book came out. That's another issue. But to say, "He's not my president," does that mean that you want no part of this country or that you don't believe in the electoral process? Or what is -- I mean, what is the point of that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, to my mind, what she's saying is she thinks this guy is not behaving in a presidential manner. And he's acting in a way that's damaging and divisive to the country. The whole -- Jesse a minute ago was talking about Roman Polanski and Dem -- liberals, I guess, more than Democrats -- excusing bad, even illegal sexual behavior. But Jesse, why wouldn't you say --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- that was wrong, and it would be wrong to do something --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would say she's saying things for cheap laughter and claps on "The View," and I can do that, too, on "The Five." I can throw out red meat all day and get claps. And not jazz hands.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK, not now, because I'm going to a tease. Don't go anywhere. "Wild Card Wednesday" is next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love that song. All right. It's time now for our brand-new edition of "Wild Card Wednesday." Judge Jeanine doesn't know what we're doing here.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So we're just going to go with the flow. She's going to have to go with the flow. OK, we each picked out a topic. We put them in the hat. We don't know which -- the stories that each of us chose, unless somebody cheated. I don't think anybody did, because we're all very good people here. OK. New study finds that more than 250 people -- 250 people worldwide have died taking selfies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Darwinism.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. OK, this was mine. They have died taking selfies in front of oncoming trains, falling from heights, and encountering wild animals. What do we think about that, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Like I said, Darwinism at its finest.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would expect more, because so many people are doing it. And because they only take the selfies in, like, dangerous areas.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like on a mountain and stuff. And then they just --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Do you see that on your cell phone? Sometimes you'll be reading an article, and then they'll have sponsored stories and it will have a picture of a woman with a snake around her neck and say, "Don't hit this unless you want to see what happened to her." I never hit. I don't want to see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I never hit it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I hit it every time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I thought your answer was great, Darwinism. Because to me it's an extension of, like, people walking down the street or crossing the street and they are looking at the cell phone. You think, wait a second. But look at this guy here off the edge of a skyscraper, off the edge of a cliff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not cool.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's just plain stupid.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Stupid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Don't do that, guys. Don't do that. All right. Not worth it. Just Photoshop yourself in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, cheat, lie. That's what Dana says.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Oh, I'm sure Greg picked this one. Your dog is probably dumber than you think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You did, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A new study finds that dogs are not a smart or special as we've been led to believe. And thinking a dog is exceptionally smart just isn't true. While they may have their own unique traits, dogs have the same intelligence level as pigeons? What?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK. I picked that one, too. Greg, I picked that one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is the best story. When I saw this, I go, "Wild Card Wednesday." I don't want to say anything. I just want to hear you people talk about this.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK, I picked this one, so I want to talk about it. My dogs are brilliant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: No. 2 on the list.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Horses are brilliant too.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Horses are? Forget horses. My dog -- there's my dog!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I had a feeling Jasper wasn't very smart.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Now wait a minute. That's not right. Jasper likes to fish. What's not smart about that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They've never invented a single thing. Dogs, animals.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What about pigeons?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Pigeons. What have they invented?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Nothing. That's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Pigs are really smart. Did you hear that? Pigs are one of the smartest.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The judge had two pigs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: For 18 years. And I wanted them to be drug pigs. I bought drug dogs for the police department. I wanted to get my pigs to be drug pigs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Find drugs with the pigs?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan, what do you think? Anything quick?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're too scared to talk about the dogs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A drug pig.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Somebody chose this one, that we had a test today for across the U.S. to receive a presidential alert. It's in case of an emergency. National Wireless Emergency Alert System. You might have gotten it on your phone. It goes, "Beep, beep, beep." Just a test. It was just a test.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So that was mine, because --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I'm trying get a reading here, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- that's unbelievable. Usually these things go off, and it's an Amber Alert or now they have Silver Alerts for the elderly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Elderly, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But it's controlled by the state and local governments. So this is the first time you have the national government, the president now controls going out, sending it. And everybody gets it. It's dangerous on one level. Because you think, hey, suddenly --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was going to say it's like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You could be taking a selfie, you know, and then that thing --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It would bad if it was hacked. FiveFanPhotoshop did one of Jasper hacking in, sending a picture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course. We did the dog thing already.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Guess what? Somebody else chose a stupid dog story. Your dog is probably dumber than you think. You?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I chose the text alert.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Then who chose --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Who chose the dog thing again?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Not me. Oh, you.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I said I did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, I did, too.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I said it. Nobody listened to me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, nobody did. I didn't think that --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I said I did it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. I thought that Greg did it to make fun of me. You did the alert?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did the alert.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because I thought it worked better than the Obamacare website.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. The last one is this -- it's the same one. Presidential alert. Like, why would the producers do that? We have to have different things.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes, producers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know, I think the producers do a really nice job.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I do not like this a lot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Let's have a round of applause for the producers. Round of applause, round of applause.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The producers. Jazz hands, everybody. Jazz hands.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, we all love this song. Listen.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So pretty much everybody knows that song. Peggy Sue Gerron Rackham, she was a real person, and there she is pictured there. She was the one who inspired one of Buddy Holiday's [SIC] big -- excuse me, Buddy Holly's biggest hits. She just passed away. She was 78 years old. She was -- the song was originally going to be called "Cindy Lou," named for Buddy's niece, but his drummer convinced him to change the name so he could impress Peggy. That's very romantic.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes, but did he ever end up with Peggy?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, he died in a plane crash.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's Buddy Holly. Did the drummer die, too?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, that's --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wait.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Buddy Holly died.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He died. I don't know about the drummer. But anyway, she -- she passed away.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The Big Bopper died. The Big Bopper died, yes. "Chantilly Lace, got a pretty face."

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes, he didn't like Peggy Sue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow. That's good, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, she did get married to the drummer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She did?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: She did?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: yes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: How do you know this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I read it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan reads the packet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I didn't actually --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan reads.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not the missile report (ph). Go ahead, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. So you know they say it's your birthday, to quote the Beatles, but what if you're a homeless child? A Pittsburgh woman doing volunteer work with the homeless began to cry when Beverly, an 11-year-old, told her she'd never had a birthday party or a slice of birthday cake. So Megs Yunn, a 33-year-old mom of four, came up with this idea. She calls it Beverly's Birthdays. And since 2012 she's put on parties for more than 30,000 children in Pittsburgh, allowing them to feel like they matter for a few hours and forget the stress of living in poverty. By the way, an estimated 2.5 million homeless kids live in the United States, and for them, Yunn's idea just terrific. It's the gift that keeps on giving, because it's a great example for us all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very nice. All right. Dustin Grasso is a trainer of mine. His son Dominic was diagnosed with juvenile diabetes. And he's got this crew, Dominic's Dominators, and there's going to be a big annual one walk, big walk, big run in the Long Island area at Hecksher State Park, Saturday October 21. And if you want to just send them some money to raise awareness and to help find a cure for juvenile diabetes, go there and check that out. And also, "Wednesdays with Watters," Martha MacCallum tonight, 7 p.m.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What will you be talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We will probably be talking about jazz hands, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Fantastic. Fantastic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I hope she claps for you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She will. I need that affirmation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So if you go to FOX News -- what is it, FOXNewsPodcast.com or podcast --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think it's FOX News.com/podcast.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Podcasts. It's podcasts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I have a -- FOXNewsPodcasts. I have a great long interview with Tucker Carlson. We talk about his new book. But mostly, we just talk about all sorts of stuff, and I mean, it's pretty brutal --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a great conversation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- pretty brutal stuff in there about his life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You really took it to him, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We took one caller. My wife called in. Called in. She didn't know I was doing a podcast at the time, so she ended up in the actual podcast.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow, that's a podcast I may actually check out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. And by the way, I talked about a lot of people. I didn't talk about you, though, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now I'm not going to listen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jeanine.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK, so I spent 30 years -- 32 years, to be exact, in law enforcement. And I saw a video, and it is -- it is all about poetic justice. I want you to watch it. Now you see what that guy is doing? He is a burglar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: He is trying to get into a restaurant. He's throwing a brick at it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The brick came back and hit him in the head?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: The brick comes back and hits him in the head. So this is, for any prosecutor, the most valuable piece of evidence you can have. You can just turn on the light and say to the jury, "Please deliberate. You heard my opening and my closing. Here's the video." So here's the deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Looks like an ice cube.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: This is a surveillance video, and this guy tried three times to get into the restaurant, which apparently has a kind of bulletproof glass that even a brick won't go through. So the crushing blow, as you can see, sends him to the ground. Then he was unconscious for a few minutes. Now, police say he tried it three times, and all three attempts were obviously unsuccessful, prompting the guy, after he passed out, to get up and leave. So my question is, you know, did they arrest him? Did they indict him? Has he been convicted?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're going to throw the brick at him.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Throw the brick at him, that is so good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Maybe he -- he could pitch --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Hey, Shannon.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS
